messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 62 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Representing Matroids over the Reals is ∃ℝ-complete

Paper Abstract: Abstract A matroid M𝑀M is an ordered pair (E,ℐ)𝐸ℐ(E,\mathcal{I}), where E𝐸E is a finite set called the ground set and a collection ℐ⊂2Eℐsuperscript2𝐸\mathcal{I}\subset 2^{E} called the independent sets which satisfy the conditions: (i) ∅∈ℐℐ\emptyset\in\mathcal{I}, (ii) I′⊂I∈ℐsuperscript𝐼′𝐼ℐI^{\prime}\subset I\in\mathcal{I} implies I′∈ℐsuperscript𝐼′ℐI^{\prime}\in\mathcal{I}, and (iii) I1,I2∈ℐsubscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2ℐI_{1},I_{2}\in\mathcal{I} and |I1|<|I2|subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2|I_{1}|<|I_{2}| implies that there is an e∈I2𝑒subscript𝐼2e\in I_{2} such that I1∪{e}∈ℐsubscript𝐼1𝑒ℐI_{1}\cup\{e\}\in\mathcal{I}. The rank 𝗋𝗄​(M)𝗋𝗄𝑀{\sf rk}(M) of a matroid M𝑀M is the maximum size of an independent set. We say that a matroid M=(E,ℐ)𝑀𝐸ℐM=(E,\mathcal{I}) is representable over the reals if there is a map φ:E→ℝ𝗋𝗄​(M):𝜑→𝐸superscriptℝ𝗋𝗄𝑀\varphi\colon E\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{{\sf rk}(M)} such that I∈ℐ𝐼ℐI\in\mathcal{I} if and only if φ​(I)𝜑𝐼\varphi(I) forms a linearly independent set. We study the problem of Matroid ℝℝ\mathbb{R}-Representability over the reals. Given a matroid M𝑀M, we ask whether there is a set of points in the Euclidean space representing M𝑀M. We show that Matroid ℝℝ\mathbb{R}-Representability is ∃ℝℝ\exists\mathbb{R}-complete, already for matroids of rank 333. The complexity class ∃ℝℝ\exists\mathbb{R} can be defined as the family of algorithmic problems that is polynomial-time equivalent to determining if a multivariate polynomial with integer coefficients has a real root. Our methods are similar to previous methods from the literature. Yet, the result itself was never pointed out and there is no proof readily available in the language of computer science.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 62 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 62"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Covering Polygons is Even Harder",
        "The Art Gallery Problem is ∃ℝℝ\\exists\\mathbb{R}-complete",
        "Training Neural Networks is ER-complete",
        "Dynamic toolbox for ETRINV",
        "Framework for ER-Completeness of Two-Dimensional Packing Problems",
        "Bounding the radii of balls meeting every connected component of semi-algebraic sets",
        "On the Computational Complexity of Decision Problems About Multi-player Nash Equilibria",
        "Topological art in simple galleries",
        "Training fully connected neural networks is ∃ℝℝ\\exists\\mathbb{R}-complete",
        "A Catalog of EXISTS-R-Complete Decision Problems About Nash Equilibria in Multi-Player Games",
        "Existential-R-Complete Decision Problems about Symmetric Nash Equilibria in Symmetric Multi-Player Games",
        "Oriented matroids",
        "On a Theory of Computation and Complexity over the Real Numbers: NP-Completeness, Recursive Functions and Universal Machines",
        "Kinser inequalities and related matroids",
        "Polytopal and structural aspects of matroids and related objects",
        "Flag matroids: Algebra and geometry",
        "Excluded minors for matroids satisfying Kinser’s inequalities",
        "Excluded minors for the class of split matroids",
        "Some Algebraic and Geometric Computations in PSPACE",
        "Intersection Graphs of Rays and Grounded Segments",
        "On Restricted Nonnegative Matrix Factorization",
        "A Universality Theorem for Nested Polytopes",
        "Completeness for the complexity class ∀∃ℝfor-allℝ\\forall\\exists\\mathbb{R} and area-universality",
        "Optimal Curve Straightening is ∃ℝℝ\\exists\\mathbb{R}-Complete",
        "Smoothing the gap between NP and ER",
        "∃ℝℝ\\exists\\mathbb{R}-Completeness for Decision Versions of Multi-Player (Symmetric) Nash Equilibria",
        "Solving Rota’s conjecture",
        "Certifying non-representability of matroids over prime fields",
        "Triangulations of algebraic sets",
        "On matroid representability and minor problems",
        "Complexity of matroid property algorithms",
        "Finding branch-decompositions of matroids, hypergraphs, and more",
        "On the minimum of a polynomial function on a basic closed semialgebraic set and applications",
        "The complexity of the Hausdorff distance",
        "Sphere and Dot Product Representations of Graphs",
        "The asymptotic number of geometries",
        "Intersection Graphs of Segments",
        "Representative sets and irrelevant vertices: New tools for kernelization",
        "Chirurgie des grassmanniennes",
        "Mnëv-Sturmfels universality for schemes",
        "Matroid matching and some applications",
        "The complexity of drawing a graph in a polygonal region",
        "Flats in matroids and geometric graphs",
        "A parameterized view on matroid optimization problems",
        "Intersection graphs of segments and ∃ℝℝ\\exists\\mathbb{R}",
        "Matroid complexity and nonsuccinct descriptions",
        "Integer realizations of disk and segment graphs",
        "On Classifying Continuous Constraint Satisfaction Problems",
        "The Universality Theorems on the Classification Problem of Configuration Varieties and Convex Polytopes Varieties",
        "Testing branch-width",
        "Matroid theory, volume 3",
        "Realization Spaces of 4-Polytopes are Universal",
        "Complexity of Some Geometric and Topological Problems",
        "Realizability of Graphs and Linkages, pages 461–482",
        "Complexity of Geometric k-Planarity for Fixed k",
        "Fixed Points, Nash Equilibria, and the Existential Theory of the Reals",
        "The Complexity of Tensor Rank",
        "A Universality Theorem for Nonnegative Matrix Factorizations",
        "The complexity of positive semidefinite matrix factorization",
        "Stretchability of Pseudolines is NP-Hard",
        "On the efficiency of representability tests for matroids",
        "Computational complexity of decomposing a symmetric matrix as a sum of positive semidefinite and diagonal matrices"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 62 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Representing Matroids over the Reals is ∃ℝ-complete, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
